ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Hands-on experience doing ethnography. Familiarity with IRB application and qualitative literature.
My ability to conduct qualitative research projects improved significantly.

I learned the ethics and the practices of field research. This includes thinking through my own positionality, as well as learning how to write field notes, conduct interviews, and conduct observation.

Practical skills: interviewing techniques, organization of field notes, how to use your data to support your argument Theoretical skills: ethical concerns, understanding of the importance of qualitative techniques to research

I got to know the practical aspects of doing fieldwork and to practice them with close supervision. I also learned about the ethical challenges of doing fieldwork and the process at the University for the review of research projects with human subjects.

The hands-on aspect of the course and its requirement for relatively extensive fieldwork is by far the most useful element. It helps apply, refine, and challenge what we read in this class and others. It is an opportunity to get our hands dirty and engage in spaces outside the comfort zone of Yale.

This course was really beneficial in terms of learning what the steps are for doing a qualitative research project. I learned more about the research process and built skills in qualitative research methods
This course was very valuable. Most importantly, I developed my interview skills and my understanding of research ethics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the professor is very good. Weakness: some readings are redundant.

I loved this course! It is an amazing hands-on practicum, which introduces students to both best practices and the city. The structure of the course is novel, the readings are excellent, and the assignments are productive. Professor Wood is a phenomenal mentor.
Strengths: lots of opportunities to practice the skills, in-depth class discussions driven by the students, guest speakers Weaknesses: directions not always clear for projects

Its main strength is its practical component, and the guest speakers were also very good. Perhaps its weakness is that we have to start doing the practical component before reading the readings on note-taking, ethnography, life history, etc. so there were some mistakes that could have been corrected preemptively.

The hands-on aspect of the course and its requirement for relatively extensive fieldwork is by far the most useful element. It helps apply, refine, and challenge what we read in this class and others. It is an opportunity to get our hands dirty and engage in spaces outside the comfort zone of Yale. The fieldwork could begin earlier in the semester i.e. cold calls, interview protocol, etc. could have earlier deadlines so that we can get into the field sooner.
The course was structured well and encouraged students to work on their fieldwork projects.

This course overall was very strong. The opportunity to do an in-depth research project and receive detailed feedback and guidance from Prof. Wood was the greatest strength. The opportunity to speak with authors about their ethnographic works was also very valuable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because learning qualitative research is important for every social scientist, and the professor is good.

Yes--the ability to conduct a research project over the course of the semester, coupled with feedback from Dr. Wood and other members of the class, was extremely useful for developing my qualitative research abilities. I feel significantly more confident to apply this to future projects.

Absolutely! This course builds important, necessary skills. The guidance you receive in unparalleled, and the opportunity to get out in the field while being able to ground and discuss the experience within a class setting is valuable.

Yes. Really looks at why you would want to do field research and the potential difficulties of doing so. Realistic in the difficulties but also inspiring in the works chosen to show the outcomes of this type of research. Terrific guest speakers who are practitioners.
Yes, it is a great way of getting a theoretical introduction and some practical experience in fieldwork
Yes. Excellent, hands-on training and detailed feedback along the way that will prove useful regardless of whether your focus is qualitative or quantitative research.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another graduate student looking to build qualitative research skills or get started on a research project.
Absolutely.
